childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1964-1976

The smell of Elmer's glue and mimeograph ink. The satisfying click of a View-Master reel advancing to the next image. The crackle of a 45 record dropping onto a turntable. Your childhood had a texture—everything was tactile, physical, present in ways that have since disappeared.

February 9, 1964—you were probably still in diapers when 73 million Americans watched the Beatles on Ed Sullivan. You don't remember it, but your older siblings do. They screamed at the TV while you gurgled in your playpen, oblivious to the fact that American culture was splitting in two right there in your living room.

At five, you watched Neil Armstrong step onto the moon. You probably didn't understand it—you were five—but you absorbed the excitement of the adults around you. 'One small step for man' played on a black-and-white Zenith or RCA Victor while your parents held their breath. For them, it was vindication after a decade of space race anxiety. For you, it was just television.

Your toys had weight to them. Tonka trucks made of actual steel that could survive being thrown down the stairs. Hot Wheels with real metal bodies that left dents in the hardwood floor. GI Joe with his realistic uniform and kung-fu grip. Easy-Bake Oven with its 100-watt lightbulb and burnt-edge brownies. Etch A Sketch that you'd shake furiously to erase your mistakes. These weren't designed for safety—they were designed to last.

Saturday mornings meant Scooby-Doo, The Flintstones, and Johnny Quest. You ate Quisp cereal from the box while lying on orange shag carpet, three feet from the television because no one had told you yet that it would ruin your eyes. The TV Guide was sacred—lose it and you'd miss The Brady Bunch. There was no recording anything, no pausing, no rewinding. You either watched it live or you missed it forever.

You were nine when Nixon resigned in August 1974. You remember your parents watching it, but you didn't understand why it mattered. What you understood was Watergate meant the cartoons got interrupted. Only later did you realize you'd watched the presidency itself crack open on live television.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Baby Boomers (The Late Wave)

Baby Boomer. You're technically one, born in the last year of the demographic bulge, but you've never quite belonged. The early Boomers—born 1946-1955—had Kennedy and Woodstock and the moon landing as teenagers. You had Watergate and gas lines and disco. Same generation, different planets.

Your birth cohort was 4 million strong—the tail end of the 76 million Americans classified as Boomers. But you arrived too late for the party. The older Boomers got the cheap college, the plentiful jobs. You got the recession of the early '80s, the savings and loan crisis, the first wave of corporate downsizing. They call you Boomers, but you grew up in their shadow.

You were five during Woodstock—too young to attend, too young to understand. By the time you were old enough for concerts, disco was dying and punk was emerging and the countercultural optimism of the '60s had curdled into cynicism. The summer of love was over before you got an invitation.

Vietnam ended when you were eleven. The draft lottery that terrorized your older brothers never touched you. You watched them come home, or not come home, or come home changed in ways they couldn't explain. The war that defined their generation brushed past you. You were the first Boomer boys who didn't have to wonder if their number would come up.

Sometimes people lump you in with Gen X—born 1965-1980—and honestly, you have more in common with them. You share the same cultural references, the same economic anxieties, the same skepticism of institutions. You're the bridge generation: Boomer by birth date, X by sensibility. You belong fully to neither.

Your generation was promised the American Dream as a birthright. Some got it. Many of you are still waiting. The narrative says Boomers had it easy, but that story erases the late Boomers who graduated into recession, bought houses at peak interest rates, and watched their pensions convert to 401(k)s. You're the forgotten trailing edge of the largest generation in American history.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Another rupture, another before-and-after, another moment when the world cracked open and revealed something darker underneath.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year you were born, the Beatles held all top five spots on the Billboard Hot 100—simultaneously. 'Can't Buy Me Love,' 'Twist and Shout,' 'She Loves You,' 'I Want to Hold Your Hand,' 'Please Please Me'—all at once. A Hard Day's Night premiered that summer. Mary Poppins in December. Dr. Strangelove taught Americans to stop worrying and love the bomb. Gilligan's Island, Bewitched, The Addams Family, and The Munsters all debuted. Pop culture exploded the year you arrived.

Your childhood was defined by television that actually taught you things. Sesame Street premiered when you were five—Big Bird, Oscar the Grouch, the pinball number song. Schoolhouse Rock launched when you were eight: 'I'm Just a Bill,' 'Conjunction Junction,' 'Lolly, Lolly, Lolly, Get Your Adverbs Here.' You learned your multiplication tables from 'Three Is a Magic Number.' You learned about the Constitution from animated songs. Education and entertainment hadn't yet separated into enemy camps.

At ten, you watched Happy Days premiere and suddenly the 1950s were cool again. At eleven, Jaws made you afraid of the water. At twelve, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest swept the Oscars. At thirteen, Star Wars changed everything—you stood in line for hours, maybe days, to see a movie that looked like nothing you'd ever imagined. That was the dividing line: before Star Wars, movies were stories. After Star Wars, movies were events.

Your teenage years gave you disco and punk existing simultaneously, which was confusing. Saturday Night Fever when you were thirteen—the Bee Gees, the white suit, John Travolta's strut. But also the Ramones at CBGB, proving you didn't need training to make music that mattered. Grease in 1978. Animal House. The Deer Hunter. You were coming of age while American culture tried to figure out what it was becoming.

At seventeen, MTV launched: 'Video Killed the Radio Star' was the first thing you saw. Suddenly music was visual. Madonna, Michael Jackson, Prince—these weren't just musicians, they were images. You watched the Thriller video at midnight and couldn't sleep afterward. You saw Michael Jackson moonwalk on Motown 25 and understood instantly that you were witnessing something that would be remembered.

Your twenties were The Breakfast Club and Ferris Bueller, Back to the Future and Top Gun. John Hughes made movies about teenagers that felt real, even though you weren't a teenager anymore. You quoted these films ironically at first, then sincerely, then just out of habit. They became the shared vocabulary of your generation.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The rotary phone in the kitchen, with its stretched-out cord that reached just far enough for private conversations in the hallway closet. The console television that took thirty seconds to warm up, with three channels and a pair of pliers where the dial used to be. The transistor radio—AM only—that you held to your ear to catch the Top 40 countdown on Sunday nights.

You were born the year IBM introduced the word processor and BASIC was invented. Computers existed somewhere, room-sized machines that only NASA and the Pentagon could afford. For you, technology meant a slide rule in math class and a typewriter for term papers. The correction ribbon was revolutionary. White-Out was miraculous.

At twelve, you saw the first Pong consoles appear in pizza parlors and bowling alleys. By thirteen, you could play it at home if your family sprung for the Atari. At sixteen, Space Invaders consumed every quarter you had. At seventeen, Pac-Man arrived, and suddenly arcades were the only place to be on Friday nights. Your thumbs developed calluses. Your parents developed concerns.

At nineteen, the IBM PC launched—$1,565 for a machine with 16 kilobytes of memory. You probably didn't buy one. But by your mid-twenties, computers were appearing in offices, and you had to learn or be left behind. WordPerfect. Lotus 1-2-3. Floppy disks that were actually floppy. You adapted because you had no choice.

At thirty-one, the World Wide Web became public. At thirty-four, you probably got your first email address—something professional on your company's server, or something embarrassing on AOL. You heard the dial-up screech and waited for webpages to load, one line of text at a time. 'You've got mail' became a catchphrase. You were old enough to find it amusing and young enough to find it useful.

At forty-three, the iPhone launched. By then you'd already survived the PC revolution, the internet revolution, email, cell phones, BlackBerrys. This was just another adaptation. You can use technology competently, but you remember when it didn't exist. That gives you perspective younger generations don't have. You know the world worked fine without all this. You're not sure it works better with it.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were eight months old when President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas. You don't remember it—you couldn't—but you absorbed the grief that hung over your childhood. Every adult who raised you remembered exactly where they were on November 22, 1963. The before and after of that day shaped the America you grew up in.

You were four when Martin Luther King Jr. was shot on a Memphis balcony, two months before Robert Kennedy was killed in a Los Angeles kitchen. The adults around you were terrified in ways you didn't understand. Cities burned. Hope died. Whatever remained of 1960s optimism bled out in 1968, the year you turned four.

At five, you watched the moon landing—or at least you were in the room while adults watched. July 20, 1969. Armstrong's boot in the lunar dust. For your parents, it was validation of American greatness. For you, it was just something that happened on TV. You assumed people walked on the moon all the time. Only later did you realize how extraordinary it was—and how quickly we stopped going.

At nine, Watergate. You remember the hearings interrupting your cartoons. You remember Nixon's face on the television, sweating, denying. You remember August 8, 1974—'I shall resign the presidency effective at noon tomorrow'—and the strange silence in your house afterward. You didn't understand the politics. You understood that the President had lied, and that lying had consequences. Except sometimes it didn't.

At eleven, Saigon fell. Helicopters on rooftops. Desperate crowds. The war that had been background noise your entire childhood ended in humiliating retreat. At twelve, the Bicentennial—red, white, and blue bunting everywhere, tall ships in New York Harbor, a country trying to celebrate itself despite everything that had just happened.

At twenty-five, you watched the Berlin Wall fall, crowds with sledgehammers and champagne. The Cold War that had defined your parents' entire existence ended in a single televised weekend. At twenty-seven, the Soviet Union dissolved. History seemed to be over. The good guys had won. Everything from here would be peace and prosperity.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you watched the towers fall. September 11, 2001. You were at work, or home, or dropping kids at school. You saw the second plane hit live. You knew immediately that the before and after of this day would define your children's lives the way Kennedy defined your parents'. The optimism of the '90s vaporized in three hours.

At forty-four, the financial system collapsed. At fifty-six, a pandemic shut down the world. 58,220 Americans died in Vietnam. History keeps happening, faster and stranger than anyone promised.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You probably graduated college around 1986, give or take—into an economy still recovering from the brutal 1981-82 recession. Jobs existed, but not as many as the older Boomers had enjoyed. The corporate ladder still had rungs, but some had been removed. You could expect to work for one company your whole career, if you were lucky, if you kept your head down, if you didn't get downsized.

Your early career was analog: typewriters, carbon copies, filing cabinets, Rolodexes. Meetings required everyone in the same room. Long-distance calls were expensive. Faxes were cutting-edge. You learned to navigate corporate culture through handshakes and memos, through water cooler conversations and three-martini lunches that were already becoming anachronisms.

Then everything computerized. Suddenly you needed to learn word processing. Then spreadsheets. Then email. Then the internet. Then smartphones. Every five years brought a new technology wave that could drown you if you didn't learn to swim. Your job description evolved continuously. The skills you'd trained for became obsolete. You adapted or you didn't—and plenty of people your age didn't.

The corporate loyalty contract shredded somewhere in the '90s. Downsizing became routine. Your pension converted to a 401(k), which meant your retirement was now your problem. The company that employed you for fifteen years would lay you off with two weeks' notice and call it 'restructuring.' You learned that loyalty was a one-way street.

You've likely worked through four recessions: early '80s, early '90s, 2001, 2008. Each one taught the same lesson: the floor can disappear without warning. At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis hit—and you watched retirement plans evaporate overnight. You're probably in the final stretch now, or already retired, navigating a world where your accumulated expertise is either invaluable or obsolete—sometimes both simultaneously. You've been reinventing yourself for forty years. You're tired. But you're still here.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when asking someone out meant calling their house, hoping their father didn't answer, and making conversation through the kitchen where their mother could hear everything? Remember when 'going steady' meant his class ring on a chain around her neck, or her sweater in his locker? Romance had protocols. Courtship had steps. Nothing was casual.

You probably got married younger than your kids will—mid-twenties was normal, late twenties was late. The wedding cost what a wedding cost back then: a few thousand dollars, maybe, for the church and the reception and the honeymoon in Niagara Falls or the Poconos. You didn't need $40,000 and a year of planning. You just needed a church that was available.

Your generation pioneered divorce, but that wasn't exactly your choice. You were teenagers when no-fault divorce laws spread through the states. By your twenties, divorce was normal—not approved, not celebrated, but no longer shameful. Some of you divorced. Some of you stayed married. The pressure to stay in miserable marriages had lifted; the support systems for ending them were still being built.

Communication in your relationships was radically different. You wrote letters—actual paper letters with stamps. You called long-distance on Sundays when the rates went down. You couldn't text your spouse during the workday; you were unreachable from 9 to 5. Somehow marriages survived without constant contact. Maybe because of it.

You've watched your children date through apps, text instead of call, swipe right and swipe left on human beings like they're browsing a catalog. It looks alien to you. But then, your parents were confused by your free-love generation, even if your actual experience was nothing like the headlines suggested. Every generation thinks the next one is doing relationships wrong.

Your friendships from college, from early careers, from young parenthood—many have lasted forty years now. You've been to each other's weddings, each other's parents' funerals, each other's children's graduations. These are the people who remember who you were before you became who you are. You don't make new friends like this anymore. You couldn't. It takes decades.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You were ten during the oil crisis of 1973—gas lines stretching around blocks, odd-even rationing, your parents genuinely worried about whether they could get to work. At fourteen, inflation hit 13.5%—money lost value while you watched. At eighteen, the prime rate hit 21.5%, the highest in American history. Your financial education happened during stagflation, when the economy could be terrible in multiple directions simultaneously.

The late Boomer paradox: you had it better than your kids and worse than your older siblings. The early Boomers bought houses in 1970 for $23,000. You bought houses in 1990 for $150,000—still affordable by today's standards, but a different game entirely. Your cohort caught the tail end of American prosperity. Enough to taste it, not enough to feast.

You probably have a pension—or half a pension, before the company converted to 401(k)s and froze what you'd accumulated. You've watched the stock market triple and crash and triple again. You've seen retirement savings evaporate in 2001 and 2008 and partially recover and wonder if there's another crash coming. You've learned that 'safe' is a myth.

Your generation controls a significant portion of American wealth, but the distribution is wildly unequal. Some late Boomers are millionaires. Many are counting Social Security checks. The average obscures the variance—and the variance is enormous. Whether you're comfortable or struggling often came down to industry luck, company luck, health luck. Skill mattered less than timing.

You've watched your children struggle with student loans, unaffordable housing, wages that don't match expenses. You've helped when you could—down payments, emergency funds, free childcare. You understand that the game they're playing is harder than the game you played. You just can't fix it for them, no matter how much you want to.

Your relationship with money is shaped by watching systems fail. The oil shocks taught you scarcity. Stagflation taught you uncertainty. The S&L crisis, the dot-com bust, 2008—each one confirmed that the floor can vanish at any moment. You save because you're afraid not to. You spend because you might not be here next year. These impulses coexist uneasily.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

The timing luck is invisible to you. You bought a house for $150,000 that's worth $600,000 now—and you think it's because you made good decisions. You got a job with a pension and stayed for thirty years—and you think it's because you were loyal and hardworking. You don't see how much was handed to you that isn't being handed to your kids. The ladder you climbed has missing rungs now. You climbed it, so you assume it's still climbable.

You've internalized 'work hard and you'll succeed' so deeply that you sometimes can't see when it's not true anymore. You made it, so clearly making it is possible. The systems that carried you have changed. The path that worked for you is overgrown and impassable now. But from where you're standing, it still looks like a path.

Technology frustration has become technology dismissal. 'I don't do computers' or 'I don't understand the cloud' isn't just a statement of preference—it's a form of opting out of the present. Your grandchildren live online. Your doctors send test results through apps. Your banks exist in browsers. The world has moved, and refusing to move with it is a form of retirement that arrives whether you're ready or not.

You can be simultaneously nostalgic for how things were and oblivious to how things were for other people. The 1950s and 1960s you remember fondly—the stability, the prosperity, the shared culture—weren't stable, prosperous, or shared for everyone. The America you grew up in was built on exclusions you didn't see because you weren't excluded.

The generational warfare bothers you, and fairly—you're not responsible for policies you didn't make. But your generation holds most of the wealth, most of the political power, most of the voting weight. 'Not all Boomers' doesn't change the structural position your generation occupies. You can be individually innocent and collectively implicated. That's uncomfortable.

You've worked hard your whole life. That's true. You've faced real challenges. That's also true. But the hardest thing to see is how much the world arranged itself around your generation—Social Security designed for your retirements, housing policy designed for your home-buying years, Medicare designed for your aging bodies—and how much it's failing to rearrange for the generations behind you.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1984-1994): Reagan era to early Clinton. You launched careers as the economy recovered from the brutal early '80s recession. MTV was new. Cocaine was everywhere. Shoulder pads were serious. You probably married younger than your kids will—mid-to-late twenties was normal. You bought a starter home with a mortgage rate that seemed high at the time (10%? 12%?) but at least houses cost less than infinity dollars. The traditional script still applied: job, marriage, house, kids. Most of you followed it, more or less, because it still worked.

Your 30s (1994-2004): Clinton prosperity to post-9/11 uncertainty. The economy boomed. The stock market seemed like it could only go up. The internet arrived, and suddenly everyone needed a website, an email address, a strategy for something called 'e-commerce.' Your career probably accelerated. Your kids were young. You watched the Berlin Wall fall and thought the future would be peaceful. Then 9/11 happened when you were thirty-seven, and everything pivoted to fear and war. The before and after of that day split your thirties in two.

Your 40s (2004-2014): Your peak earning years coincided with the worst financial crash since the Great Depression. You were forty-four when Lehman Brothers collapsed. You watched your 401(k) lose 40% of its value and wondered if you'd ever retire. Your kids became teenagers, then young adults, and launched into an economy with no jobs. You couldn't protect them from it. You could only watch and help where possible and feel guilty about having had it easier.

Your 50s (2014-2024): Recovery, sort of. The economy improved. Your investments recovered. But the world felt stranger—political polarization, social media toxicity, a pandemic that isolated everyone. Your parents were aging and dying. Your kids were struggling in ways you didn't fully understand. You were sandwiched between generations, responsible for everyone, supported by no one. At fifty-six, COVID locked you in your house and reminded you that the future is never guaranteed.

Your 60s and beyond (2024+): You're here now, or approaching it. Retirement is either happening or a fantasy, depending on how the math worked out. You're navigating aging in a medical system designed to confuse you and a culture that worships youth. Your grandchildren live in devices you don't entirely understand. The world moves faster than you do now. But you've survived things that would have broken lesser generations. The moon landing, Watergate, stagflation, AIDS, 9/11, the Great Recession, COVID. You're still standing. That's not nothing.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as you—the final cohort of the 76 million Boomer generation. You're at the tail end of the largest generation in American history, until Millennials overtook you. You came too late for the full Boomer experience and too early for Gen X. You're a hinge generation, belonging fully to neither.

Compared to Early Boomers (born 1946-1955): They got there first and got the best of everything. College tuition they could pay with a summer job. Houses for two years' salary. Pensions—actual pensions—that paid for life. They were old enough for Woodstock and the Summer of Love. You were old enough for disco and Saturday Night Fever. They came of age during the longest economic expansion in American history. You came of age during stagflation. Same generation, different economic universes.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): They're your younger siblings, practically—one year separates you. You share more cultural touchstones with them than with early Boomers. You both survived corporate downsizing, the death of pensions, the digital transition. The difference: you remember the old world more clearly. You had a few more years of the old social contract before it was shredded. They never expected stability; you expected it and had it taken away. Both are bitter, but for different reasons.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): Your children, many of them. Your generation controls 52% of American wealth while comprising 21% of the population. At their age, they control 7%. You bought houses before they became unaffordable—and you know, even if you don't always admit it, that your kids couldn't buy the house you raised them in. The numbers are what they are.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Your grandchildren, some of them. They've never known a world without internet, without smartphones, without school shootings. They've never expected the systems to work. They're building around broken institutions rather than trying to fix them. You worry about them. But they might be more prepared for the future than anyone realizes—they've been training for chaos their whole lives.

Your life expectancy at birth was 70 years. If you've made it to sixty, actuarial tables give you another twenty-plus. You'll likely see 2040, maybe 2050. You'll watch the climate crisis unfold, the AI revolution, the demographics of America shift past majority-minority, whatever comes next. You've already watched more history than most generations see in a lifetime. There's more coming. There always is.

year_events: The Beatles arrived in America and played Ed Sullivan
The Civil Rights Act was signed by President Johnson
GI Joe action figures debuted from Hasbro
The Ford Mustang was introduced to America
Pop-Tarts hit grocery store shelves for the first time
